column2: Look round the habitable world, how few Know their own good, or, knowing it, pursue!
column3: Look round the habitable world, how few Know their own good, or, knowing it, pursue!

column2: Those who govern, having much business on their hands, do not generally like to take the trouble of considering and carrying into execution new projects.
column3: Those who govern, having much business on their hands, do not generally like to take the trouble of considering and carrying into execution new projects.

column2: The best public measures are therefore seldom _adopted from previous wisdom, but forc'd by the occasion_.
column3: The best public measures are therefore seldom underscore adopted from previous wisdom, but forc'd by the occasion underscore.

column2: The Governor of Pennsylvania, in sending it down to the Assembly, expressed his approbation of the plan, "as appearing to him to be drawn up with great clearness and strength of judgment, and therefore recommended it as well worthy of their closest and most serious attention." The House, however, by the management of a certain member, took it up when I happen'd to be absent, which I thought not very fair, and reprobated it without paying any attention to it at all, to my no small mortification.
column3: The Governor of Pennsylvania, in sending it down to the Assembly, expressed his approbation of the plan, "as appearing to him to be drawn up with great clearness and strength of judgment, and therefore recommended it as well worthy of their closest and most serious attention." The House, however, by the management of a certain member, took it up when I happen'd to be absent, which I thought not very fair, and reprobated it without paying any attention to it at all, to my no small mortification.

column2: XV
column3: fifteen

column2: QUARRELS WITH THE PROPRIETARY GOVERNORS
column3: QUARRELS WITH THE PROPRIETARY GOVERNORS

column2: In my journey to Boston this year, I met at New York with our new governor, Mr. Morris, just arriv'd there from England, with whom I had been before intimately acquainted.
column3: In my journey to Boston this year, I met at New York with our new governor, mr Morris, just arriv'd there from England, with whom I had been before intimately acquainted.

column2: He brought a commission to supersede Mr. Hamilton, who, tir'd with the disputes his proprietary instructions subjected him to, had resign'd.
column3: He brought a commission to supersede mr Hamilton, who, tir'd with the disputes his proprietary instructions subjected him to, had resign'd.

column2: Mr. Morris ask'd me if I thought he must expect as uncomfortable an administration.
column3: mr Morris ask'd me if I thought he must expect as uncomfortable an administration.

column2: I said, "No; you may, on the contrary, have a very comfortable one, if you will only take care not to enter into any dispute with the Assembly." "My dear friend," says he, pleasantly, "how can you advise my avoiding disputes?
column3: I said, "No; you may, on the contrary, have a very comfortable one, if you will only take care not to enter into any dispute with the Assembly." "My dear friend," says he, pleasantly, "how can you advise my avoiding disputes?

column2: You know I love disputing; it is one of my greatest pleasures; however, to show the regard I have for your counsel, I promise you I will, if possible, avoid them." He had some reason for loving to dispute, being eloquent, an acute sophister, and, therefore, generally successful in argumentative conversation.
column3: You know I love disputing; it is one of my greatest pleasures; however, to show the regard I have for your counsel, I promise you I will, if possible, avoid them." He had some reason for loving to dispute, being eloquent, an acute sophister, and, therefore, generally successful in argumentative conversation.

column2: He had been brought up to it from a boy, his father, as I have heard, accustoming his children to dispute with one another for his diversion, while sitting at table after dinner; but I think the practice was not wise; for, in the course of my observation, these disputing, contradicting, and confuting people are generally unfortunate in their affairs.
column3: He had been brought up to it from a boy, his father, as I have heard, accustoming his children to dispute with one another for his diversion, while sitting at table after dinner; but I think the practice was not wise; for, in the course of my observation, these disputing, contradicting, and confuting people are generally unfortunate in their affairs.

column2: They get victory sometimes, but they never get good will, which would be of more use to them.
column3: They get victory sometimes, but they never get good will, which would be of more use to them.

column2: We parted, he going to Philadelphia, and I to Boston.
column3: We parted, he going to Philadelphia, and I to Boston.

column2: In returning, I met at New York with the votes of the Assembly, by which it appear'd that, notwithstanding his promise to me, he and the House were already in high contention; and it was a continual battle between them as long as he retain'd the government.
column3: In returning, I met at New York with the votes of the Assembly, by which it appear'd that, notwithstanding his promise to me, he and the House were already in high contention; and it was a continual battle between them as long as he retain'd the government.

column2: I had my share of it; for, as soon as I got back to my seat in the Assembly, I was put on every committee for answering his speeches and messages, and by the committees always desired to make the drafts.
column3: I had my share of it; for, as soon as I got back to my seat in the Assembly, I was put on every committee for answering his speeches and messages, and by the committees always desired to make the drafts.

column2: Our answers, as well as his messages, were often tart, and sometimes indecently abusive; and, as he knew I wrote for the Assembly, one might have imagined that, when we met, we could hardly avoid cutting throats; but he was so good-natur'd a man that no personal difference between him and me was occasion'd by the contest, and we often din'd together.
column3: Our answers, as well as his messages, were often tart, and sometimes indecently abusive; and, as he knew I wrote for the Assembly, one might have imagined that, when we met, we could hardly avoid cutting throats; but he was so good natur'd a man that no personal difference between him and me was occasion'd by the contest, and we often din'd together.

column2: [Illustration: "One afternoon, in the height of this public quarrel, we met in the street"]
column3: [Illustration: "One afternoon, in the height of this public quarrel, we met in the street"]

column2: One afternoon, in the height of this public quarrel, we met in the street.
column3: One afternoon, in the height of this public quarrel, we met in the street.

column2: Franklin, says he, "you must go home with me and spend the evening; I am to have some company that you will like;" and, taking me by the arm, he led me to his house.
column3: Franklin, says he, "you must go home with me and spend the evening; I am to have some company that you will like;" and, taking me by the arm, he led me to his house.

column2: In gay conversation over our wine, after supper, he told us, jokingly, that he much admir'd the idea of Sancho Panza,[93] who, when it was proposed to give him a government, requested it might be a government of _blacks_, as then, if he could not agree with his people, he might sell them.
column3: In gay conversation over our wine, after supper, he told us, jokingly, that he much admir'd the idea of Sancho Panza,[ninety three] who, when it was proposed to give him a government, requested it might be a government of underscore blacks underscore, as then, if he could not agree with his people, he might sell them.

column2: One of his friends, who sat next to me, says, "Franklin, why do you continue to side with these damn'd Quakers?
column3: One of his friends, who sat next to me, says, "Franklin, why do you continue to side with these damn'd Quakers?

column2: Had not you better sell them?
column3: Had not you better sell them?

column2: The proprietor would give you a good price." "The governor," says I, "has not yet _blacked_ them enough." He, indeed, had laboured hard to blacken the Assembly in all his messages, but they wip'd off his colouring as fast as he laid it on, and plac'd it, in return, thick upon his own face; so that, finding he was likely to be negrofied himself, he, as well as Mr. Hamilton, grew tir'd of the contest, and quitted the government.
column3: The proprietor would give you a good price." "The governor," says I, "has not yet underscore blacked underscore them enough." He, indeed, had laboured hard to blacken the Assembly in all his messages, but they wip'd off his colouring as fast as he laid it on, and plac'd it, in return, thick upon his own face; so that, finding he was likely to be negrofied himself, he, as well as mr Hamilton, grew tir'd of the contest, and quitted the government.

column2: These public quarrels[94] were all at bottom owing to the proprietaries, our hereditary governors, who, when any expense was to be incurred for the defense of their province, with incredible meanness instructed their deputies to pass no act for levying the necessary taxes, unless their vast estates were in the same act expressly excused; and they had even taken bonds of these deputies to observe such instructions.
column3: These public quarrels[ninety four] were all at bottom owing to the proprietaries, our hereditary governors, who, when any expense was to be incurred for the defense of their province, with incredible meanness instructed their deputies to pass no act for levying the necessary taxes, unless their vast estates were in the same act expressly excused; and they had even taken bonds of these deputies to observe such instructions.

column2: The Assemblies for three years held out against this injustice, tho' constrained to bend at last.
column3: The Assemblies for three years held out against this injustice, tho' constrained to bend at last.

column2: At length Captain Denny, who was Governor Morris's successor, ventured to disobey those instructions; how that was brought about I shall show hereafter.
column3: At length Captain Denny, who was Governor Morris's successor, ventured to disobey those instructions; how that was brought about I shall show hereafter.

column2: [93] The "round, selfish, and self-important" squire of Don Quixote in Cervantes' romance of that name.
column3: [ninety three] The "round, selfish, and self important" squire of Don Quixote in Cervantes' romance of that name.

column2: [94] My acts in Morris's time, military, etc.--_Marg. note_.
column3: [ninety four] My acts in Morris's time, military, etc--underscore Marg. note underscore.

column2: But I am got forward too fast with my story: there are still some transactions to be mention'd that happened during the administration of Governor Morris.
column3: But I am got forward too fast with my story: there are still some transactions to be mention'd that happened during the administration of Governor Morris.

column2: War being in a manner commenced with France, the government of Massachusetts Bay projected an attack upon Crown Point,[95] and sent Mr. Quincy to Pennsylvania, and Mr. Pownall, afterward Governor Pownall, to New York, to solicit assistance.
column3: War being in a manner commenced with France, the government of Massachusetts Bay projected an attack upon Crown Point,[ninety five] and sent mr Quincy to Pennsylvania, and mr Pownall, afterward Governor Pownall, to New York, to solicit assistance.

column2: As I was in the Assembly, knew its temper, and was Mr. Quincy's countryman, he appli'd to me for my influence and assistance.
column3: As I was in the Assembly, knew its temper, and was mr Quincy's countryman, he appli'd to me for my influence and assistance.

column2: I dictated his address to them, which was well received.
column3: I dictated his address to them, which was well received.

column2: They voted an aid of ten thousand pounds, to be laid out in provisions.
column3: They voted an aid of ten thousand pounds, to be laid out in provisions.

column2: But the governor refusing his assent to their bill (which included this with other sums granted for the use of the crown), unless a clause were inserted exempting the proprietary estate from bearing any part of the tax that would be necessary, the Assembly, tho' very desirous of making their grant to New England effectual, were at a loss how to accomplish it.
column3: But the governor refusing his assent to their bill (which included this with other sums granted for the use of the crown), unless a clause were inserted exempting the proprietary estate from bearing any part of the tax that would be necessary, the Assembly, tho' very desirous of making their grant to New England effectual, were at a loss how to accomplish it.

column2: Mr. Quincy labored hard with the governor to obtain his assent, but he was obstinate.
column3: mr Quincy labored hard with the governor to obtain his assent, but he was obstinate.

column2: [95] On Lake Champlain, ninety miles north of Albany.
column3: [ninety five] On Lake Champlain, ninety miles north of Albany.

column2: It was captured by the French in 1731, attacked by the English in 1755 and 1756, and abandoned by the French in 1759.
column3: It was captured by the French in seventeen thirty one, attacked by the English in seventeen fifty five and seventeen fifty six, and abandoned by the French in seventeen fifty nine.

column2: It was finally captured from the English by the Americans in 1775.
column3: It was finally captured from the English by the Americans in seventeen seventy five.

column2: I then suggested a method of doing the business without the governor, by orders on the trustees of the Loan office, which, by law, the Assembly had the right of drawing.
column3: I then suggested a method of doing the business without the governor, by orders on the trustees of the Loan office, which, by law, the Assembly had the right of drawing.

column2: There was, indeed, little or no money at that time in the office, and therefore I propos'd that the orders should be payable in a year, and to bear an interest of five per cent.
column3: There was, indeed, little or no money at that time in the office, and therefore I propos'd that the orders should be payable in a year, and to bear an interest of five per cent.

column2: With these orders I suppos'd the provisions might easily be purchas'd.
column3: With these orders I suppos'd the provisions might easily be purchas'd.

column2: The Assembly, with very little hesitation, adopted the proposal.
column3: The Assembly, with very little hesitation, adopted the proposal.

column2: The orders were immediately printed, and I was one of the committee directed to sign and dispose of them.
column3: The orders were immediately printed, and I was one of the committee directed to sign and dispose of them.

column2: The fund for paying them was the interest of all the paper currency then extant in the province upon loan, together with the revenue arising from the excise, which being known to be more than sufficient, they obtain'd instant credit, and were not only receiv'd in payment for the provisions, but many money'd people, who had cash lying by them, vested it in those orders, which they found advantageous, as they bore interest while upon hand, and might on any occasion be used as money; so that they were eagerly all bought up, and in a few weeks none of them were to be seen.
column3: The fund for paying them was the interest of all the paper currency then extant in the province upon loan, together with the revenue arising from the excise, which being known to be more than sufficient, they obtain'd instant credit, and were not only receiv'd in payment for the provisions, but many money'd people, who had cash lying by them, vested it in those orders, which they found advantageous, as they bore interest while upon hand, and might on any occasion be used as money; so that they were eagerly all bought up, and in a few weeks none of them were to be seen.

column2: Thus this important affair was by my means completed.
column3: Thus this important affair was by my means completed.

column2: Mr. Quincy return'd thanks to the Assembly in a handsome memorial, went home highly pleas'd with this success of his embassy, and ever after bore for me the most cordial and affectionate friendship.
column3: mr Quincy return'd thanks to the Assembly in a handsome memorial, went home highly pleas'd with this success of his embassy, and ever after bore for me the most cordial and affectionate friendship.
